The member, Mrs. Epifania, is 29 years old, married, and has three children.  She divides her time between taking care of her daily chores and her business selling small animals like chickens, guinea pigs, and pigs.  She is also a farmer and plants corn on some land she has.  She sells the animals at various fairs around the Urubamba province.  Her husband works selling corn he takes to different places like Calca, Anta, and Urubamba.  The member wants to grow her animal raising business so she is taking out a loan to buy animals and feed for animals.  The member is happy about the loan and promises to comply with her payments.

loans.use: This member is taking out a loan to buy animals and animal feed.

loans.name: Godwin

texts.en:
Godwin, age 28, earns a living as a tomato farmer. He has been growing tomatoes for 10 years, and the business has allowed him to cater to his family's needs. He faces a significant challenge in the high operational costs of his business, such as paying for labor and for sprays. 

Godwin's dream is to diversify and venture into onion growing as well. It is in pursuit of this goal that Godwin is requesting this loan: he intends to clear a portion of his land for onion farming.

Godwin and his wife own a temporary house in Fort Portal, Uganda, where they live with their two children. Godwin is the sole breadwinner of the family. His desire is eventually to build a permanent house for his family.

loans.use: to clear a portion of his land for onion farming

loans.name: Mourine

texts.en:
Mourine is a 45-year-old, single mother of three children living in her own house in Kamwenge, Uganda. Ever since she separated from her husband, she has been looking after the family by herself. Her dream is to be able to provide her children with higher levels of education.

For 6 years Mourine has been selling food. Her desire is to own a food store in town despite challenges of unsettled debts by some customers. Mourine needs the loan to buy beans and maize for resale.

loans.use: to buy beans and maize for resale

loans.name: Rose Fe

texts.en:
Rose Fe is 33 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with two children.

Rose Fe has a retail shop that sells green bananas & coconuts. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan for 5,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) to buy coconuts and bananas to sell.

Rose Fe is a new member of HSPFI. In the future, Rose Fe hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy coconuts and bananas to sell.

loans.name: Nouhoum

texts.fr:
Monsieur Nouhoum est un homme marié de 51 ans et père de 3 enfants. Il vit avec sa femme et ses enfants chez son oncle dans une famille traditionnelle élargie, à Bougouni, dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord.
N’ayant pas fréquenté l’école moderne, dès son jeune âge il commença les activités génératrices de revenus.
Durant des années, il mena les activités d’achat et de vente de poissons, mais cette activité ne lui a véritablement pas souri. C’est ainsi que depuis 3 ans il décida de changer d’activité pour mener les activités d’achat et de vente de boeufs. Il a appris cette activité auprès de son ami.
Ayant fait la connaissance de Soro Yiriwaso à travers sa femme qui est une cliente de l’institution, il décida de prendre lui aussi un prêt pour acheter quelques quatre à cinq boeufs. Il s’approvisionne à Bougouni et dans les villages environnants. Il effectue sa vente au marché à bétail de Bougouni et une partie à Bamako, à une clientèle composée essentiellement de bouchers.
Monsieur Nouhoum compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75.000 FCFA.
Avec ce bénéfice il envisage construire une maison  à usage d’habitation et agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en: Mr. Nouhoum is a 51-year-old married father of three. He lives with his wife and children at his uncle’s home in an enlarged traditional family in Bougouni, in the Hérémakono Nord neighborhood. Having not attended modern school, he has been working for a living since he was young. For years, he has been buying and selling fish, but this business has never truly appealed to him. This is why three years ago, he decided to change his business to buy and sell oxen. He learned how to conduct this business from a friend. Having been introduced to Soro Yiriwaso by his wife, who is one of their clients, he decided to take a loan to buy four or five oxen. He stocks up in Bougouni and neighboring villages. He sells at the cattle market in Bougouni and a part of Bamako to a clientele primarily composed of butchers. Mr. Nouhoum plans to earn 75,000 FCFA monthly. With his profit, he envisions building a house to live in and to grow his business.

loans.use: to buy oxen

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en: Catherine is 34 years old, married to Alfred who is a primary school teacher. She is blessed with two children aged six and four years. She operates a cosmetic shop in Kapsabet town and has been in the business for six years earning a monthly income of KES. 10,000. With need for growth and expansion of her business, she has borrowed a second loan from KADET LTD of KES. 60,000 to enable her to purchase weaves, body lotions, hair dyes, hair braids and hair treatments for her business. The anticipated profits she will use to diversify her business. Her dream is to own her own plot and build a personal house.

loans.use: To purchase stock like weaves, body lotions, hair dyes, hair braids & hair treatments

loans.name: Ana Rosario

texts.es:
Ana de 38 años, es una mujer trabajadora que decidió hace 20 años atrás tener un pequeño negocio de confección de ropa y así darse tiempo para pasar con su familia. Poco a poco fue mejorando sus ingresos. 

En la actualidad su horario de trabajo es desde las 08h00am hasta las 20h00pm en donde confecciona todos los pedidos que le piden sus clientes y vecinos.  Tiene muchas aspiraciones que su negocio mejore sus ingresos por eso desea el préstamo para comprar cemento, arena, bloques y ampliar su negocio para que el espacio físico no le impida atender a mas clientes ya que su negocio está en la parte delantera de su casa. En el fututo desea tener un taller de confección con maquinas industriales.
texts.en:
Ana is 38 years old. She is a hardworking woman who decided 20 years ago to open a small business making clothes to have time to spend with her family. Little by little she improved her income. 

At present, her work schedule is from 8:00 am till 8:00 pm. She makes all kinds of things that her customers and neighbors order. She aspires to improving her income and for that she wants a loan to buy cement, sand, and blocks to expand her business so that the physical space won't stop her from serving more customers, since her business is in the back of her house. In the future, she wants a workshop with industrial machines.

loans.use: to buy cement, sand, and blocks to expand her business.

loans.name: Asoono

texts.en:
Asoono is 40 years old and married with 1 child. She owns and operates a business venture, selling a variety of different products in the local community.  She has many years of experience in this business.    Asoono needs a loan of WST 2,000 to purchase additional products to sell.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or $125 per week) to financially support immediate members of her family.

In 2009, Asoono joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral.  This is her 3rd loan with SPBD. 



*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers.  Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the ""overall social metric score.""  For example, a 3 out of 3 on ""level of education"" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.  

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda is 42 years old and is a married woman with 3 children aged 21, 17 and 13. She lives in the town of Cortes, Bohol, with her family. Her husband owns and manages a mechanic shop.

Yolanda makes baskets for a living. She uses "buri" (a type of palm) to make baskets. She earns about 6000 PHP per month with her business. She requested a loan to purchase buri and other materials for making baskets. She hopes to be successful in her business so she can help her husband sustain their family.

loans.use: buy basket-weaving materials

loans.name: Justo Pastor

texts.es: Justo Pastor se dedica al comercio de leña  y madera aserrada, tiene 20 años de tener este negocio. Aprendió este negocio por su papa, pero fue con fondos propios que él decide establecer este medio de vida. El tiene 3 hijos bajo se su cargo de 14, 16 y 16 años respectivamente el siempre se preocupa por brindarles lo necesario como vestimenta, educación y alimentación. El motivo del crédito es para la compra de madera al por mayor, pues ya tiene una muy buena oferta por eso quiere comprar.
texts.en: Justo Pastor has worked selling lumber for more than 20 years.   He learned this work from his father, but it was with his own money that he decided to start his business.   Justo is responsible for 3 children, ages 14, and twins who are 16, and he is always worried about providing them with the food, clothing and education they need.  This loan will be used to purchase the wood at wholesale prices.  He has been offered a good price and would like to purchase the lumber.

loans.use: to purchase lumber at wholesale prices

loans.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
Arlyn is 20 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with five children. 
Arlyn provides pedicure and manicure services. She has run this business for ten years. She has requested a loan of 7,000 PHP to buy materials needed to provide her services.
Arlyn has been a member of Kiva partner HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Arlyn hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy materials needed to provide her services.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: La socia desea el prestamo para invertir en la compra de un artefacto para su hogar; la socia compra diversos electrodomesticos y otros para implementar su hogar y paga poco a poco las cuotas en el banco con lo que le remuneran en su trabajo, la socia en esta ocasion desea comprar una computadora para uso personal. la socia tambien da clases de reforzamiento de forma particular; la socia desea seguir prosperando para dar mejor calidad de vida. La socia solicita el prestamo para invertir en la compra de una computadora para uso personal.
texts.en: This client wants to invest the loan to buy an artifact for her home. She will buy various appliances and other things to improve her home and will make payments little by little to the bank with income from her job. In particular, this client wants to buy a computer for personal use. She also gives personal development classes. She hopes to continue prospering in order to improve her quality of life. She is asking for the loan to buy a computer for personal use.

loans.use: to buy a computer for personal use.

loans.name: Benson

texts.en:
Benson  is 33 years old and married to Mary, who runs a green grocer. They have two children.

He has been selling spare parts for the last ten years, and he earns a monthly profit of KES. 20,000.  

He has applied for his first loan of  KES 50,000 from KADET Ltd. He plans to use the loan to buy more stock of spare parts such as headlights, side mirrors and back lights for sale.

He will save the anticipated profits to provide the basic needs for his family. 

Benson hopes to grow his business and open a big wholesale shop in the future.

loans.use: To add stock of spare parts such as headlights, side mirrors and back lights for sale.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es: Rosa de 66 años de edad vive al sur occidente de la ciudad, con su esposo y tiene 2 hijos en las edades de 32 y 40 años. Allí se dedica a la venta de bebidas frías, desde hace aproximadamente 10 años;  ella en su casa vende cervezas y refrescos, que almacena en un botellero de 500 unidades, a clientes que lo compran para ser consumidos en su lugar de residencias. Su meta es lograr ampliar su negocio y ofrecer un servicio siempre oportuno a su clientela. En la actualidad se acercó a la Fundación Maro Santo Domingo, para solicitar su credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a esta organización,  con el que comprará bebidas para enfriar y vender en la etapa más festiva y familiar del año, las navidades y el año nuevo. Su sueño es convertirse en proveedora de tiendas y pequeños negocios, que usualmente se quedan sin inventarios y deben esperar el vehículo de reparto semana a semana, para responder a sus clientes. Así mismo mediante su trabajo espera más adelante mejorar sus condiciones habitacionales y sentirse confortable con todo lo que Dios le ha dado.
texts.en:
Rosa, 66, lives to the southwest of the city with her husband, and has two children, ages 32 and 40.  There she has worked selling cold drinks for approximately 10 years.  In her house she sells beer and soft drinks, which she stores in a 500-unit bottle rack, to customers who buy it to drink in their homes.  Her goal is to manage to expand her business and always offer her customers a timely service.

Currently she approached Mario Santo Domingo Foundation to request a Kiva loan, the first funding she has requested from this organization.  With it she will buy drinks to chill and sell in the most festive and family-oriented season of the year, Christmas and New Year.

Her dream is to become a supplier for stores and small businesses (which usually end up without inventory and have to wait for the weekly distribution), to be able to meet the demand of her customers.  She also hopes through this work to improve her living conditions in the future and to feel more comfortable with what God has given her.

loans.use: to buy drinks to chill and sell.

loans.name: Avtandil

texts.en:
Avtandil lives in the village of Kandaura, East Georgia with his family, wife Nanuli, son and a daughter-in-law. Avtandil is 64 years old. He leads the agricultural business of the family. His son works as a driver at a local milk processing company. Avtandil’s daughter-in-law works as a teacher. Nanuli is a housewife. The family has 2 cows. Nanuli produces cheese and sells it locally to dairy product retailers. Also they have a vineyard on a family-owned plot of land and sell grapes. Total average monthly income of the family is 750 Laris. Avtandil requested credit for purchasing feed for the cows for the winter months. Also, part of the funds will be spent on modifying the engine of Avtandil’s car to make it more cost effective, in terms of consumed fuel. 

As the cows will be fed well, Avtandil will get the planned amount of milk and dairy products during the winter months. The family will continue sales of the dairy products, which is an important source of the income for them.

loans.use: to purchase feed for cows

loans.name: Pors

texts.en:
Pors, 53, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She and her husband have been involved in agriculture for over six years. They have extensive experience and are successful in their business. 

Pors is involved in growing rice. Her children are construction workers. In order to improve her family's finances, Pors is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase rice to resell at the rice mill. This will allow her to generate more income to support the family.

In the future, she would like to expand her agricultural business and build a new house.

loans.use: to purchase rice to resell at the rice mill.

loans.name: Lorn's Group

texts.en:
Lorn, 62, lives in a rural area of the Kror Kor district of Pursat Province, Cambodia, and has four children. To make a living, she has engaged in rice-farming and pig-raising for twenty-five years. She also supplemented her income by selling various kinds of vegetables to help the family generate income. 

She is able to earn about KHR 18,000 per day and manages to save about KHR 10,000 each day after offsetting daily expenses. Insufficient working capital is the main challenge for her current business. 

Lorn’s group consist of three members who live in the same village, and she is in her first loan with VisionFund. She is requesting a loan of KHR 300,000, while the remaining two members are requesting a loan of KHR 1,000,000 each. As the leader, Lorn is going to utilize her portion as additional working capital in buying more vegetables for selling, such as cucumbers, cabbages, chilies, etc. She hopes this loan will enable her to increase her income from the current business so as to keep up good progress in her lifestyle.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables for selling

loans.name: Emelita

texts.en:
Emelita is a married woman, 58 years old with two children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur.

Emelita has a food vending business in the Philippines. Emelita requested a PHP 14000 loan amount through NWTF to buy ingredients like meat, fish, pork, spices, vegetables and other materials for her food production business.

Emelita has been in this business for 3 years. She would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients like meat, fish, pork, spices, vegetables and other materials for her food production business

loans.name: Angelina Lopez

texts.en: My name is Angelina LÃ³pez and I sell accessories for sewing;  I also tailor clothing for women.  Iâ€™ve been tailoring for the past fifteen years and selling the accessories for the past two. I need the credit in order to buy the necessary cloth to make school uniforms.

loans.use: Buying cloth, zippers, buttons and lace

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria I. is a very enterprising woman. She has dedicated herself for one year to the sale of jewelry, principally gold bracelets. She is requesting a loan of $1200 to buy merchandise. She plans to repay it in 12 months.

(Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

Maria I. es una mujer muy emprendedora, ella tiene 1 año dedicandose a la venta de joyeria, principalmente pulseras de oro, ella solicita $1,200.00 dllrs para Compra de mercancía y piensa pagarlo en un plazo de 12 meses.

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Sahnaz

texts.en: Sahnaz is 44 years old and lives with four family members in Kabul City. Her husband has five years experience repairing bicycles and motor bikes. Sahnaz is requesting a loan so her husband can buy bicycle parts and other materials for his shop. This loan will help him rebuild his shop and satisfy customer demand. It will also help their family meet their living expenses and improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase bicycle parts

loans.name: Shirin

texts.en:
Shirin is a 50 year old Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Djabrayil region, settled in Absheron region. He is  married and has 5 children.
At the beginning of his business he sold  agricultural produce in the market. Then he started selling  seasonal vegetables and fruits also.
One day he decided to buy a truck for transportation of goods.
Now he has transported the vegetables and fruits from the different regions and sells wholesale to market.  He also transports  goods by customer request. to different places.
Shirin needs a loan of $1200 to do capital repairs on  the chassis ( motor  and etc.) of his truck.

loans.use: To do capital repairs  on the the chassis ( motor  and etc.) of his truck

loans.name: Gulnora

texts.ru:
Gulnora K., 41 is married and has 3 children. Her husband has a seasonal job selling vegetables; her children are in school. Gulnora has a high school education. Gulnora’s oldest son helps her to sell. Before becoming a MicroInvest client in 2006, Gulnora relied on high-interest loans from illegal lenders. Having earned a reputation of responsible borrower and with the help of MicroInvest tiered credit program, Gulnora began to pay cash to purchase her goods and personally deliver them. She also increased the assortment of the goods sold. The value of Gulnora’s business assets grew up to $600. In the future, she plans to offer fashionable clothing for all ages.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Каримова Гулнора 41лет. Замужем, мать троих детей. Муж занимается сезонной торговлей овощей, дети учатся в школе. Образование среднее. Старший сын помогает матери в торговле. Стала клиентом “Микроинвест” в 2006 году. До этого брала средства для оборота у местных нелегальных кредиторов под большие процентные ставки. Благодаря пошаговому кредитованию и ее ответственностью перед политикой МЗФ она стала покупать товар за наличные, стала ездить за товаром сама, увеличила ассортимент товара. Сейчас ее активы достигли около 600$ . А в будущем планирует привозить модные одежды для всех поколений.

loans.use: Increase variety of goods sold

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
For 5 years, Virginia O. F. has had a small home business selling clothes for children and adults. She is in a very busy location near the center of the city and many people pass by on their way to work.

This business helps her husband with family expenses and supporting their children. She is requesting a loan of $250 to purchase more clothing to sell.

loans.use: Purchase children's and adults' clothing to sell

loans.name: Dora

texts.en: Dora S. is 35 years old and married with 5 children. She owns a small shop in the town of Makeni in Sierra Leone. Her husband serves as a local court clerk, and Dora has to earn an income to supplement his meager income. She started her business by selling in the open air market, and with previous loans she managed to rent a small shop. Her plan is to increase her stock and diversify the business. She is therefore requesting a $300 loan.

loans.use: Diversify and increase her stock of goods for her general store.

loans.name: Joe's Group

texts.en:
Joe N. bakes bread and cakes. She wants to purchase more trays and raise her level of profits so that she can send her 7 children to a boarding school.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: Purchase more baking equipment

loans.name: Nabweru South Ii(D) Group

texts.en:
Sharifa, Kevina, Madina, and Muyiga have been together for fifteen months. Sharifa currently makes and sells snacks. She would like to set up a retail shop. Muyiga runs a clinic and would like to purchase more furniture. Suzan owns a drug store, Madina has a beauty salon, and Kevina has a brick laying business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To increase her business volume

loans.name: Hospital East C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Rehema N.. She is currently in the business of running a grocery store and is requesting a loan to purchase more groceries. Rehema is 32 years old and is married. Her husband is a driver. She has 4 children ranging from age 8 to 14 and her children go to school. Each week, Rehema makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a wholesale shop. Rehema has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to buy more groceries and the loan was paid back on time.

Rehema is joined in her small group by Silisata N., Jesca Katembe and Lydia N.. Silisata N. has a business running a retail shop and wants to increase the stock of shop items. Jesca Katembe is currently operating a business selling new clothes and wants a loan to add to her business. Lydia N. operates a business running a beauty parlor and wants to purchase more cosmetics.

loans.use: To expand grocery business and make more profits

loans.name: Edither

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is Edither K.. She is 29 years old, married, and has one 3-year-old child. Edither owns a clothing and cosmetics business, and she works extremely hard to support her family. Edither seeks a loan in order to purchase additional stocks of shoes, cosmetics, bags, and clothing. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro-finance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are not considered to be credit-worthy by financial institutions because they lack tangible assets that can serve as collateral. As such, low income women in Tanzania typically receive poor financial support and in turn only limited access to basic needs and services.

Fortunately, SELFINA has been a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women in Tanzania. Simply put, SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women through an arrangement called a sale and leaseback transaction. More specifically, when a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extends a loan to her to facilitate the transaction, and then leases the equipment back to her.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of shoes, clothes, bags, and cosmetics.

loans.name: Maria Isabel

texts.es:
Isabel is married, and her husband works as a laborer. Together they have one son. She started this business to help her husband with the family expenses and make ends meet given their situation at the time. The little income her husband earned was not enough to subsist and lead a better quality of life. She started two years ago with a little stand where she sold soft drinks and tostadas (a popular Mexican dish) up until she opened her own grocery store, which she still runs today.

Currently, she is requesting a loan for US $150, which she will repay in 3 months, to invest in merchandise and do some minor remodeling to her business.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

Isabel es casada su esposo trabaja como obrero y tiene un hijo. Inició el negocio para apoyar a su esposo con los gastos familiares y salir adelante dado la situación que pasaban en ese momento. El poco ingreso con que contaba su esposo no era suficiente para subsistir y llevar un mejor nivel de vida. Comenzó hace 2 años con un pequeño puesto de refrescos y tostadas hasta tener ya su propio negocio la tienda de abarrotes con el que hoy cuenta.

Actualmente solicita un crédito por US $150 que pagara en 3 meses para invertir en mercancía y realizar una pequeña remodelación en su negocio

loans.use: Comprar mercancia

loans.name: Anar

texts.en:
Anar M. is a 30-year-old farmer who sells dairy products to the local people and the local milk factory. In fact, he has more than twenty years of experience in this particular field. He lives with his family in the small village of Saatli, and he has been an internally-displaced person since 1993.

Selling milk and yogurt is the only source of income for his family, a fact that Anar is mindful of as he seeks to generate additional income from his business. Accordingly, he is requesting a loan in the amount of $700 to purchase one dairy cow which will enable Anar to earn more money and to thereby stabilize his family's financial situation.

loans.use: To expand his business and to generate additional income for his family by purchasing a dairy cow

loans.name: Lun

texts.en: Lun K. L., 26, is married and lives with her one young child in the Kampong Cham province. She works in a garment factory, making $3 each day, while her husband works security and makes $5 each day. The garment factory is not really close to her home, and the transportation costs have begun to accumulate for Lun K. L. and her husband. She is asking for a loan of $1200 to purchase a motorbike for commuting to and from work. The money she will be able to save on transportation costs will allow her to increase her income and possibly raise her standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Mohammad Smail

texts.en:
Mohammad Smail is 47 years old, married, living in a household of 8 members. He has a retail shop and one of his sons is working with him. He was 22 years old when he started up his business and still he is working.

So he wants to buy some tanks of gas to start up gas selling. He has requested an individual loan to complete his stock and make new section for gas inside his shop. He has 200,000 Afghani (about US$ 4350) retail value in his shop. Now he wants to take a loan in the amount of 50,000 Afghani (US$ 1,100) with a term of 18 months to further these two businesses. He hopes to further enlarge his business in the future.

loans.use: To complete his stock and make new section for gas

loans.name: Danaya (Trust) Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Danaya  (trois mariées et une célibataire )ont une moyenne d’âge de  28 ans et  2 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles polygames traditionnelles au quartier Sogomougou de la ville de Koutiala (troisième région économique du Mali ).
Elles mènent différentes activités notamment  la vente de bois pour la construction, la restauration ( exclusivement nocturne) etc. Unis par des liens professionnel, de voisinage et de groupe d’âge, les membres du groupe dans leur souci d’augmenter la taille de leurs activités, ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant deux ans.
Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de groupe (prêt solidaire) et les deux premiers ont été remboursés sans difficulté.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter la contenance d‘un camion en bois de constuction, un sac de haricot, des cartons de macaronie et une quantité importante d’ingrédients pour la restauration. Elles s’approvisionnent dans les villages voisins de Koutiala auprès des exploitants forestiers pour le bois de construction et au grand marché de la ville pour les ingrédients de la restauration nocturne.
Les entrepreneurs du batiment sont les principaux clients du bois de construction. Par contre la clientèle est très diversifiée pour la restauration en raison de la proximité du lieu de vente à une zone très fréquentée par les noctambules. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice par cycle de 80 000 CFA.qu’elles envisagent utiliser pour payer les intérêts du prêt et faire face aux charges courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The four women in the Danaya group (three are married and one is single) are on average 28 years old and have two children. They live in traditional polygamist families in the Sogomougou neighborhood in the city of Koutiala (third economic region of Mali). They run different businesses, notably in the sale of construction wood, food-service (exclusively at night), etc. United by profession, neighborhood, and age, in trying to grow their businesses, the group members decided to use microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso’s credit program, which they have been doing for two years. They are on their third group loan, and their first two were repaid without difficulty. The current loan will be used to buy a truckload of construction wood, a bag of beans, boxes of macaroni, and a large quantity of ingredients for their food-service business. They stock up in Koutiala’s neighboring villages from forest farmers for the construction wood and at the city’s big market for the ingredients for the nocturnal food-service. Building entrepreneurs are the principal clients of the construction wood. On the other hand, the food-service clientele is diversified because of the proximity of the location to an area frequented by night owls. They hope to earn 80,000 CFA francs each per cycle, which they foresee using to make loan payments and meet the ongoing needs of their families.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase construction wood and ingredients for food-service

loans.name: Luz Y Vida Group

texts.en:
The Luz y Vida (Light and Life) group is made up of 13 people, of whom four are men and nine are women. All of the group members live in the same zone of Munaypata, a neighborhood in El Alto, BoliV.. The members are involved in different economic activities, such as selling athletic and American clothing, food, and sweets. Some of the men in the group work as drivers.

Betty is the group president. She has three children, and works as a street vendor selling large shopping bags and sweaters. Her husband is a contractor. The treasurer, Jannett, is single and sells handicrafts; she is also studying. The secretary, Esther, has one son and runs a lunch counter, which does very well.

The group gets along very well. The women worked together previously with another financial institution, so they know each other very well. Most of the group members plan to use this loan to increase their inventory of products so that they can earn more money.

loans.use: Buy bulk merchandise to resell

loans.name: Moeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Moeurn H. is a pig breeder in Trapaing Krasang Village in Takeo Province. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets for breeding; if there is any money left over, she will use it to buy pig food. Mrs. Moeurn H. is a 37-year-old widow with three children, one of whom is a construction worker; the other two are still attending the local school.

loans.use: Purchasing more piglets and pig food

loans.name: Bapane

texts.en: Bapane N. is married and has 4 dependents. She has received no formal education. Bapane sells yams at Praso market in Elmina, which she has done since 1998. Her husband is a farmer. Bapane uses her income to pay utility bills and other family expenses. Bapane will use the loan to purchase more yams to increase her sales to meet her increased customers' needs. With the new profits from her expanded business, Bapane plans to help her husband build a family house.

loans.use: purchase more yams to increase her sales

loans.name: Marcela

texts.es: Marcela tiene 52 años D. edad, es casada, tiene 3 hijos, ahora está viviendo solo con el mayor. Hace 20 años atrás se dedicaba  a la venta D. comida, pero le era muy trabajoso y dificultoso, entonces, hace 8 años comenzó a vender productos D. belleza, dice que le va bien, sobre todo le deja márgenes D. ganancia muy alentadores porque tiene clientas buenas pagadoras, pero hace como 2 años decidió implementar el negocio con la venta D. prendas D. vestir, pero con lo que más gana es la venta D. perfumes y joyas D. catálogos muy conocidos. Y ahora hace como 4 meses que está cuidando a la hija D. su sobrina, la cual le da una propina por eso, la dificultad es que tiene que ofrecer sus productos cargando a la pequeña. Es su 5to préstamo con Microfinanzas Prisma. El dinero solicitado lo va invertir en la compra D. perfumes, ella trata D. estoquear su negocio por campañas, ya que le dan a un menor costo y los pueD. vender D. acuerdo al precio del catalogo y gana más.
texts.en:
Marcela is 52 years old and married with three children, though only the oldest lives with her. Twenty years ago, she worked selling food, but it was a very difficult job for her so eight years ago she started selling beauty products. She tells us that the business is going well and overall she earns very encouraging margins on her products since her customers pay her well and on time. About two years ago, she decided to set up a business selling clothing, but she earns more selling perfumes and jewelry from very well-known catalogues. About four months ago, she took over the responsibility of taking care of her niece's daughter (for which she earns a bit of money) but now her difficulty is that she has to carry the girl as she walks around selling her products. This is her 5th loan from Prisma Microfinance and she will use the money to buy perfumes. She tries to stock her business in phases since she receives better pricing as she buys in bulk and she is able to earn greater profits.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase the stock of products she sells

loans.name: Irma Del Socorro

texts.es: La Sra. Irma tiene 28 años de edad, habita en el  barrio Villa Reconciliación de la capital de Managua, casada, tiene tres preciosos hijos de 8, 10 y 12 años de edad todo estudiantes, los planes para su familia es ofrecerle un porvenir mejor. La Sra. Velásquez tiene su pequeño negocio una tienda de ropa desde hace siete años de experiencia en ventas, sus metas es incrementar su ventas, generándoles mayores ganancias, lo inicio con fondos propios con esta solicitud del préstamo va a comprar ropa variada para niños y adultos, y comprar ropa escolares ya que viene el ingreso a clases y se vende bastante la ropa escolar y así obtener un ingreso económico para su hogar
texts.en:
Mrs. Irma is 28 years old and lives in the Villa Reconcilación neighborhood of Managua, the capital. She is married and has three precious children, 8, 10 and 12 years old who are students. She plans to offer her family a better future. Mrs. Velásquez has had her small business, a clothing store, for seven years and has experience in sales. Her goals are to increase sales and generate larger profits. She began with her own capital. With this loan application she is going to buy varied clothing for children and adults. She is also going to buy school clothing since classes start soon and school clothing sells well. This way she will have an income for her home.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Haynes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase varied child and adult clothing

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence A. is 57 years old and married with six children. She sells plastics like plates, bowls, and cups at Oge market in Ibadan, Nigeria. She needs the loan amount of N70,000 to purchase additional plastics to sell. She says thank you to everyone that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more plastics to sell

loans.name: Koch

texts.en: C., 24, has been raising pigs in a stall next to her house for a long time, and is earning an average of US$ 5 per day. She is married with three children. She currently lives in Pursat Province with her husband, who is a local farmer. C. hopes to have a rice-husking machine that would be a main source of additional income for family. Therefore, she is requesting a loan to add to her personal savings to purchase a rice-husking machine to provide a rice hulling service for villagers for a fee.

loans.use: To purchase a rice-hulling machine

loans.name: Twendenawakati Group

texts.en:
Helen M. is 55 years old and a widow with five children ages 34, 30, 25, 20 and 17 years.  She has a chicken business she started in 1994. She works daily from 6am until 7pm and is able to earn a monthly profit of around $154. 

This will be Helen’s sixth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to buy more chickens and pay school fees.  She has repaid the loans successfully and hopes for a sixth loan to buy more chickens and to start selling milk and soda. 
	
Helen will share this loan with her loan group, Twendenawakti, which totals 15 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Helen in the front in blue.

loans.use: Buy more chickens and start to sell milk and soda

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en: Sorn K. is 42 years old and sells palm sugar in Takeo province. His business has been around for about twenty years and he makes US$100 every month. His wife, Nhem Chanthoeun, 41, pictured here, is a vegetable seller in the market, and she is able to make US$20 in revenue per day. Sorn K. is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase palm sugar to sell. He sees this investment as an opportunity to increase his daily income.

loans.use: To purchase palm sugar to sell.

loans.name: Juana Leonor

texts.es:
Juana es socia del Banco Comunal Alborada.
Juana es casada, tiene 40 años y 4 hijos, Juana tiene una tienda en su casa en donde vende abarrotes en general, carnes, verduras, gas, actividad que realiza todos los días con la ayuda de una persona.
Juana necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz, leche, azúcar.
Juana sueña con que sus hijos sean profesionales y ampliar su negocio.
texts.en:
Juana is a member of the Alborada community bank. Juana, 40, is married and has 4 children. Juana has a grocery store; she sells meat, vegetables and gas. She works every day and has one helper. Juana needs a loan of 1,000 PEN to buy rice, milk and sugar. Juana’s dream is for her children to become professionals and to expand her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, milk, and sugar.

loans.name: Clara

texts.en: Clara E. is 56 years old. She is a widow with 7 children. She sells medicine. She hopes for a loan in the amount of NGN100,000 ($700 US) so that she can purchase more medicine to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine to sell.

loans.name: Darius

texts.en:
Darius is only 24 years old, but he is already married to Ashley and they already have one child named Darvie Miacheal, now 3 years old. They reside in an urban area of Calamagui 1st Ilagan, Isabela. Darius is very happy and proud to have a family that is peaceful and loving. He is praying that this kind of relationship in their family will remain the same for the years to come. He is also grateful for having his wife who is very supportive and is always helping him improve their market vending business. According to Darius, he will do everything he can to succeed in life as long as he has the strength to do so for the welfare of his family. Go confidently in the direction of your dreams, live the life you imagined, he adds.

Darius is requesting a loan from lenders amounting to PHP 6,000 as additional working capital to his small snack vending stall in the market. Darius, together with his wife, is selling cooked snacks such as “pansit”, banana-cue, juices, soft drinks, etc. He is hoping for his business to grow by working diligently so he can also uplift his family's way of living. He is planning to save some of his income for the future schooling of his son and future children.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en: Julieta P. is from Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She is 33 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. Julieta owns and operates a "sari-sari" (general) store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Julieta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Julieta is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 8th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Alejandra

texts.en:
Alejandra I. is from the town of Katipunan. She is 54 years old. Alejandra is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Milagros owns & operates a business planting & harvesting fruits & vegetables for sale. Alejandra has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Alejandra joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Alejandra has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. She is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, to be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Alejandra from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.
 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, such as manure.

loans.name: Obidamo

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 


Давлатова Обидамо занимается продажей мужских брюк на рынке "Корвон". Обидамо 1961 года рождения и имеет  5 детей. Имеет среднее образование. Так как ее муж не очень хорошо зарабатывает, она старается много работать и зарабатывать больше денег, чтобы прокормить семью. Обидамо  закупает свой товар из оптового рынка  «Корвон». Она хочет получить средства с помощью Кива кредиторов и расширить ассортимент своего товара, для привлечения клиентов.
texts.en:
Obidamo D. sells men's trousers at the Korvon market. Obidamo was born in 1961 and has 5 children. She has secondary education. Because her husband does not earn very much, she tries to work a lot and earn more money in order to support their family. Obidamo buys her merchandise at the Korvon wholesale market. With the help of Kiva creditors, she wants to obtain means to expand her merchandise assortment in order to attract customers.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expanding merchandise assortment

loans.name: Ankadjidia 3 De (Ankadjidia De Zoha) Group

texts.fr:
Les huit femmes du groupe ANKADJIDIA 3 sont toutes mariées et  résident à zoha, un village de la sous-préfecture de Fakola, préfecture de Kolondièba dans la troisième région (Sikasso) de la république du Mali. Elles ont  une moyenne d’âge de 25 ans, 3 enfants et vivent dans des familles polygames. Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage. 
.Avec l’ouverture du  prêt de campagne de Soro Yiriwaso, qui correspond avec leur activité étant paysannes, ces femmes ont saisi l’occasion. Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt de campagne, tous les trois précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Elles veulent utiliser ce prêt actuel pour les frais de labour,  de sarclage, l’achat de semences, d’engrais et d’herbicides. Elles envisagent exploiter  4 hectares en arachide, riz et mil pour une production estimée en moyenne à  2  tonnes par hectare soit 8 tonnes. 
Une partie de la récolte sera vendue dans les différentes foires hebdomadaires et le reste  sera destiné à la nourriture.
Le bénéfice de  la vente sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt, prendre en charge les frais scolaire, la santé des enfants et acheter les trousseaux  de mariage des filles.
texts.en:
The 8 women of the ANKADJIDIA 3 group are all married and live in Zoha, a village in the Sous-Prefecture of Fakola, Prefecture of Kolondièba in the third region (Sikasso) of the Republic of Mali. They have an average age of 25, 3 children each on average, and live in polygamous families. They met due to bonds of kinship and neighborhood.

When Soro Yiriwaso began to give rural loans which correspond to their work as farmers, these women seized the opportunity. They are on their fourth rural loan, and the three preceding ones were correctly reimbursed.

They want to use this new loan to pay for plowing and weeding, and to buy seeds, fertilizer, and herbicides. They want to plant 4 hectares of peanuts, rice, and millet with an average production estimated at 2 tons per hectare, or 8 tons in all. A part of the harvest will be sold in the various weekly markets and the rest destined for consumption.

The profit from their sales will be used to reimburse the loan, cover school fees, for the health expenses of their children, and for buying wedding trousseaux for their daughters.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: plowing, seed, fertilizer, herbicide, and weeding

loans.name: Luz Helena

texts.es:
La señora LUZ HELENA B. E. , tiene 42 años, vive en el distrito de Moche , provincia de Trujillo, departamento La Libertad – Perú.
Pertenece al Banco SEÑOR DE LA PIEDAD II.
La empresaria presenta estudios hasta 5º de secundaria, tiene  4 hijos de años quienes  depende económicamente de ella, porque aún se encuentran en el colegio.
LUZ se dedica a la preparación de pan, biscochos, roscas en la panadería instalada en su casa para luego vender a los diferentes panaderos y tiendas quienes revenden el producto.
Su primer crédito de 300 nuevos soles lo invirtió en la compra abarrotes, tales como: harina, mantequilla, pasa, huevos, etc
Este crédito de 1000 nuevos soles lo utilizará para comprar mas productos  como harina. mantequilla y utensilios de cocina.
LUZ sueña con ampliar su negocio y obtener mayores ganancias.

loans.use: comprar productos  como harina, mantequilla y utensilios de cocina.

loans.name: Hasna

texts.en:
Hasna is a 46-year-old woman who lives in the Bekaa Valley where she owns a grocery store. Hasna’s store is a success because she knows how to treat her clientele, who are her friends and neighbors. She decided to go into business in 2002 because she wanted to work.

Hasna has requested a loan of 2000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase more merchandise for her store. This is the first time that she has requested a loan. Hasna plans to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her store

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
María tiene 50 años, vive con su esposo y sus hijas en su casa propia. Desde muy joven ha incursionado en varios negocios para poder brindarle a su familia una buena calidad de vida. Ahora que sus hijos ya están grandes y formaron su propia familia, ella desea que sigan su ejemplo, es por ello que los apoya cada vez que quieren enrumbar un negocio. Por tal motivo, junto a su hija han decido vender comida y desde hace algunos días se han instalado en una de las calles más concurridas de su distrito con un puesto de comida. Su hija es quien administra el negocio y cocina los ricos platillos, mientras que María la ayuda en la atención de la clientela. Para el futuro esperan tener un restaurante y extender su negocio.
Este es su tercer préstamo con MFP y siempre ha sido muy puntual y responsable en el momento de pagar sus cuotas. Este es su tercer préstamo con MFP y siempre ha sido muy puntual y responsable en el momento de pagar sus cuotas.
texts.en:
María is 50 years old and lives with her husband and daughters in their own house. Since she was very young, she has ventured into many businesses so that she can offer her family a good quality of life. Now that her children are grown-up and have their own families, she wants them to follow her example. Because of this, she supports them each time they want to start a business. For this reason, she and her daughter have decided to sell food and for many days, they work in one of the busiest streets in their area with a food stall. Her daughter manages the business and cooks the delicious plates, while María helps her take care of the clients. In the future, they hope to have a restaurant and grow their business. This is her third loan with MFP, and she has always been very punctual and responsible in her repayments.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cooking utensils and furniture for her business

loans.name: Wilson's Group

texts.en:
Wilson M. is 37 years old and the leader of his group in Bushenyi. He is married with three children, who are all currently enrolled in school. Wilson has been farming his whole life and has been operating his own banana plantation for 20 years. He would like to use the loan to generally improve the conditions of his plantation, thereby increasing crop yields.

Wilson believes that larger harvests will allow him to begin supplying organizations and big towns with bananas. He hopes that with his continued hard work, one day he will be able to send all of his kids to university.

loans.use: Improvements to Banana Plantation

loans.name: Dora

texts.es:
Dora es una mujer de 54 años, ella es muy trabajadora y su mayor deseo es mejorar sus condiciones de vida. Vive con sus 5 hijos quienes le brindan su apoyo incondicional.

Desde muy joven trabajó vendiendo diversos accesorios para damas, pero cuando se casó dejo de trabajar con el fin de atender su hogar. Sin embargo, la muerte de su pareja la obligó a retomar su actividad comercial, y desde hace 10 años viene trabajando en la venta de cosméticos y ropa, labor que realiza con mucha alegría, brindado a sus clientes una atención de calidad. 
Dora considera que lo rentable de su actividad depende de la compra, al por mayor, de los productos, además de las ofertas que hay en los catálogos, pues después de un tiempo puede venderlos a los precios habituales. 
Sus planes a futuro son de implementar una tienda de accesorios de belleza y productos cosméticos, en su misma vivienda.

Este es su primer préstamo individual con Microfinanzas PRISMA, anteriormente fue parte de un banco comunal, por lo que sabe que siendo puntual en sus pagos tendrá la posibilidad de seguir accediendo a otros créditos, los cuales le brinden la oportunidad de seguir mejorando como comerciante. Con el dinero que ahora solicita comprará grandes cantidades de productos de belleza para venderlos en estas próximas festividades navideñas.
texts.en:
Dora is 54 years old. She is a hardworking woman whose greatest wish is to improve her living conditions. She lives with her 5 children who provide her with unconditional support.

Since she was a young woman, Dora has been selling women’s accessories but stopped working when she got married so that she could take care of the household. However, the death of her husband forced her to resume working. She has now been selling cosmetics and clothing for 10 years. Dora takes great joy in her work and provides her customers with quality service.

She considers her line of work to be profitable because she can purchase her products at wholesale through catalogs and then sell them at retail prices. Her future plans include opening a store out of her home where she sells cosmetics and beauty accessories.

This is Dora’s first individual loan with Microfinanzas PRISMA. She was previously a member of a Communal Bank, so she knows that she has to make her payments on time in order to be eligible for future loans and have the opportunity to grow as a businesswoman. With the money she requested, Dora will purchase large quantities of beauty products to sell during the upcoming holiday festivities.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase beauty products

loans.name: Saua

texts.en: Saua M. (0) is a 44-year-old woman living in the town of Faleasiu, Tualesolo. She is married and has three school-aged children. Saua owns and operates a business planting and harvesting bananas for sale. She has been engaged in this business for over two years and earns approximately 350 WST a month. In 2009, Saua joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting a loan of 1,000 WST which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. The loan will be her first from SPBD. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About SPBD: SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self-esteem.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Juliecris

texts.en:
Juliecris C. is from the village of Centro Napu in Tudela,Misamis Occidental. She is 20 years old. Juliecris is married and has one young children. To make a living, Juliecris just started a business raising and selling pigs.

In 2009, Juliecris joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juliecris is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be Juliecris's first loan from PMPC. She plans to save the additional revenue generated from the business for future emergencies. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe V. is 46 years old and a good mother to her three children, She is married to her compassionate spouse Arnulfo V., a farmer and tricycle driver. They currently live at an attractive place, Morong, Rizal. She is engaged in a farming business and also get involved in hog raising (raising of pigs).

Presently two of her children are studying in college and one is a nursery student. She hopes to finish the studies of children through the benefit of having loans from ASHI, KIVA's field partner. She believes that her business will help her family to rise up and fight against poverty, as well as provide for the educational needs of her 3 children and enable them to have a comfortable house to live in.

She plans to utilize this loan of Php 45,000 to expand her farming business and get involved in other businesses for supplementary profits. This loan will be used to buy fertilizer (Php 30,000.00), pigs (Php 8,000.00), and feed (Php 7,000.00). During her 10 years as a member of ASHI, Fe V. has shown very good performance, and she is being trusted by ASHI for the length of time she stayed. Having this loan will enable her to finally achieve her dreams in life: to have a winning business, the best in life, and a happy family as well. She is very thankful to ASHI for the continued support of her dreams.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, pigs, and feed for pigs

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
K. is a 35-year-old married man with two children.  One of his children is currently in school, while his other child is still very young.  In recent months, he has been struggling to provide for his children's basic needs (e.g., education), which has been his greatest challenge.  But he explains that he is constantly working to provide for his children and to pay his bills.  

K. supports his family by working as a trader.  Specifically, for 11 years now, he has been in the business of selling used clothing and bed sheets.  Selling such items is big business in Ghana because brand-new cloths are too expensive for much of the population.  He travels to a nearby city known as Kumasi to purchase his stock of goods.  He is seeking a loan to buy more bales of used clothing.  Normally, he concentrates on selling children's clothing, bed sheets, used towels, etc.  He believes that this loan would help him save for his children's future.  In addition, he hopes that the loan will one day enable him to rent a store where he could trade his goods because he typically sells his goods through hawking.

loans.use: To expand his inventory by purchasing additional clothes

loans.name: Manuela

texts.es:
La Sra. Manuela, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Esmeralda”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia de San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 42 años y es madre de 03 hijos, 02 que aun dependen de ella y están estudiando.

El espíritu luchador que siempre le ha caracterizado y las ganas de salir adelante con sus propios medios le ha valido para iniciar su propio negocio de venta de anticuchos en las fueras de su casa, donde poco a poco fue haciéndose muy conocida entre sus clientes y hoy nos cuenta que le va muy bien en este tipo de actividad.  Sus ventas lo realiza  diariamente  a partir de las 6:00pm. Lleva aun poco tiempo trabajando en este tipo de actividad y se siente muy contenta con lo que hace.
 
Con este préstamo de S/ 2,000.00, comprará insumos como arroz en sacos, huevos, gallinas criollas para sus juanes y pollos desviscerados para sus anticuchos, asimismo utensilios de cocina para brindar un servicio de calidad.  

Manuela, se siente muy tranquila y contenta con lo que hace  y  agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir  con el cumplimiento de sus sueños y metas.
texts.en:
Manuela belongs to the Esmeralda Communal Bank in the Tarapoto District, San Martin Province, Region of San Martin. She is single, forty-two years old and the mother of 3 children, 2 of whom she still supports and are in school. The fighting spirit that she has always had and the desire to get ahead using her own means have been valuable to her in starting her own business selling anticuchos (meat skewers) outside of her home. Little by little she has become more well-known among her customers and today she tells us that this type of work is going very well for her. She begins selling every day starting at 6:00pm. Although she has not been doing this type of work for very long, she feels very content with it. With this loan of 2000 soles, Manuela will buy supplies like bags of rice, eggs, chickens for her tamales and butchered chicken for her anticuchos (meat skewers), as well as cooking utensils in order to offer quality service to her customers. Manuela feels very happy and peaceful in her work and is grateful to the Manuela Ramos Movement for helping her to fulfill her dreams and her goals.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Eldridge, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies for food preparation

loans.name: Chreng

texts.en: Mrs  Chreng C., 31, has worked as a professional chef for more than four years. She was been married for many years to Sokhunthea, 30,  who helps support the family by working as a blacksmith. The couple has two school-aged children who are dependent on their income. Chreng's husband has been engaged in his business for years, but he needs more accessories to perform his service. C. is therefore asking for a loan to buy a generator and other supply tools which will benefit her husband's business. (Mrs. C.'s husband appears in the photo above.)

loans.use: To buy a generator and other supply tools for her husband's business

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en:
Blessing is 32 years old, married to a businessman, and has four children. Her youngest child is three years old. Her children are still dependent on her and they go to school.
Blessing sells dried fish to make a living in Sapele. In Nigeria, dried fish is an essential ingredient in the preparation of a local soup like egusi (melon soup), and so demand is high. Blessing loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She sells her dried fish at retail prices to customers. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more dried fish to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more dried fish to sell

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia W. is from the village of Binaliwan, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 56 years old. Virginia is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Virginia makes and sells cakes and pastries in the local community. Virginia has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately $115 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Virginia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virginia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make her products. This will be her 3rd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells

loans.name: Ginabelle

texts.en:
Ginabelle, 23, is a rice farmer in Bunawan, Agusan del Sur. She needs farm inputs to operate her rice field but she lacks capital. That's why she sought help from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., requesting a loan of 14,000 Php. This loan will enable her to provide the supplies needed for her farm.

Ginabelle is the mother of two children, her eldest being only 4 years old. Rice farming is the only way she can provide the basic needs of her family.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Mairam's Group

texts.en: There is a proverb that says an empty cart rumbles more than a packed one. A lot of people tend to teach others how to settle things and organize one's own life. Well, there are a lot less people who take substantial steps towards accomplishing their aims rather than just nattering on about it. Mairam O. is a leader of this group. She is sixty-one years old. Mairam has raised six children. Her eldest son is forty and her youngest son is twenty-four years old. Having had this many children, who are now grownups and already have their own families and earn their own livelihoods, Mairam could now excuse herself from any work. But it is not in her nature to be a couch potato and occupy herself with idleness. Instead, she makes handicrafts and sells them to foreign customers. First she presented her works to one foreign company and made a contract with them to make handicrafts for them. She also worked as a consultant. Recently, she has secured a big order for handicrafts and now is working on it. Mairam has even gotten her daughter involved in this business, to prepare the order in time. Now, Mairam needs a loan to buy materials for making handicrafts. Mairam’s partners are: Kerez A., 61, is a manufacturer of national articles. Her husband is officially retired but he works part time as a technician. Kerez and her husband have raised six children. Kerez needs a loan to buy materials. Burul J., 33, is single. She lives with her mother and produces national articles. Her sisters help her buy materials. Burul wants to obtain this loan buy materials for making articles. Svetkul A., 56, is a mother of four children. Svetkul runs a non-government organization “Altyn Kol”, which promotes handicrafts. Svetkul needs a loan to purchase materials. Upol M., 55, is a widow. She has four children. She is also a member of “Altyn Kol”. Upol is occupied with manufacturing national articles as well as works as an accountant. She hopes to obtain this loan to purchase materials. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy materials for making handicrafts

loans.name: Gina

texts.en: Gina Y. is from the village of Digkilaan, Iligan City. She is 40 years old. Gina is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Gina makes and sells food. The main source of income for her business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Gina has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Gina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Gina is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will also be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the third loan taken out by Gina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to further improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Nyamishamba Twetungure A, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
Operating a retail shop alongside tea growing is a formidable business venture that has seen B. Ezra manage life to this day in Nyamishambya, Kihihi.

It is always difficult for many youth here in Uganda to settle for farming rather than spending time drinking alcohol and gambling, but Ezra is now different in economic terms. Having gotten a little capital to start up his retail business that fetches him 240,000 monthly, he is seeking a loan to expand his business into a wholesale operation and to purchase enough stock since there is a ready market from customers.

loans.use: To  purchase more stock and transform his business into a wholesale operation

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: José Alfredo

texts.es: El  señor José Alfredo G. R. es padre de familia preocupado por el bienestar de sus 3 hijos a los que quiere ofrecer comodidad. Es por ello que el quiere terminar de construir un cuarto que tiene en la planta alta de su casa, que con mismos prestamos de esta institución ha levantado pero por falta de capital aún no lo termina. El señor Alfredo necesita el apoyo para comprar el material de construcción y así terminar el cuarto y así ofrecer a su familia confort.
texts.en:
Sr. José Alfredo G. R. is a father who is concerned about the welfare of his three children for whom he wants to provide comfortable conditions. For this reason, he wants to finish the construction of a room on the upper floor of his house. With the loans from FVP, he was able start this project but he does not have the capital to finish it.

Sr. Alfredo needs this assistance so that he can buy the construction materials needed to finish the room and provide greater comfort for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Finish the construction of a room

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites S. is from the village of  Consuelo, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 38 years old. Marites is married and has 3 adult children. Marites owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells food & daily use products. She has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Marites joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Marites has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. She is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Marites from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand his business and buy more seeds for his farming

loans.name: Kodirjon

texts.en:
Kodirjon is a very responsible and hardworking father who has been dedicated to his business of buying and selling clothing for many years. The need to improve his income and provide education to his two dear children is the reason he is courteously requesting this loan. Kodirjon has so far accessed loans from Kiva partner, IMON International, twice and has seen his business expand. With the income, he said he was able to educate his children, which is most important to Kodirjon. Today, he is requesting a loan of 5000 TJS to expand his business so that he can generate more income for the wellbeing of his family. Kodirjon is very grateful to everyone who helps him achieve his dreams with this loan.

More about Tajikistan
Tajikistan, a key post on the Silk Road, is perhaps best known for its rich history. It was the location for the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and is known for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country, with its epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mix of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR, damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 per cent of the country is mountainous and only 7 per cent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands of people to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need.
